top_comment.text:
Way less crime? No. Some crimes have decreased, some violent offenses have 
had no change or even increased. Overall, there hasn't been much change. 
Again, this is 3 months into legalization, and as director of Rocky 
Mountains High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area, Tom Gorman, an accurate 
view won't be had for another 3/4 years. Nonetheless, any decrease now or 
in the future may not be caused by decriminalization, and may not be 
repeated in other states or societies. PLOS One finds that “Perhaps the 
more likely explanation of the current findings is that (these) laws 
reflect attitudes and behaviors that have been established in those 
societies...If their attitudes and behaviors reflect a more tolerant 
populace that is less likely to infringe on one another’s personal rights, 
we are unlikely to expect an increase in crime and might even anticipate a 
slight reduction in personal crimes.”

Decriminalization, for example, would not nothing in Mexico, where cartels 
are involved in trafficking of legal substances, like oil, coal and 
alcohol.﻿
top_comment.author: ChristianMission

comments.text:
Orthodox it would not shut down the cartels they would just move to a 
different drug
comments.author: Tim Morgan

comments.text:
Decriminalization 'would not nothing in Mexico'?  Do you mean it wouldn't 
solve anything, or would do nothing?  The cartels receive hundreds of 
millions of dollars of income due to illegal marijuana sales.  It would do 
something.  It wouldn't shut them down, but it would be like taking away a 
rich man's credit cards... they'll feel the pinch.  Less money to bribe the 
police, mayors and politicians.

I agree its too early to tell if there has been an effect on crime by 
legalization, but your bias in attempting to dispel and argue away any 
possible benefits implies if the result does not match the 
pre-decriminalization scaremongering, you will continue to argue it away. 
 Thankfully there are enough example grounds occurring in the country that 
the truth will come out, and no one body, union, or congregation, will be 
able to stifle it. 

More freedom, no more crime, and more happiness (/less pain)... a 
celebration all around.  :)
comments.author: OrthodoxAtheist

comments.text:
+C0ct0pusPrime it is a plant, yes, but like i said earlier, it's not the 
plant that's illegal, it's using it as a DRUG that is. 
i do fully see the good points. but you have to acknowledge the bad. and

the government made it legal? it would become like tobacco; the price would 
definitely rise, because i don't know about your country, but our MP's just 
seem to love swimming in our money; they would also spray it with 
chemicals, and possibly (probably) make it physically addictive (i think it 
is addictive anyway, but suit yourself). another thing, it would lose its 
"cool", and it wouldn't be as "rebellious" for teenagers to do. now here i 
have to agree with you, it's not as bad as say cocaine. that's why i'd 
rather have my child smoke weed than crack. i'm not sure how valid you find 
this last argument, or any of them for that matter, but i think 
realistically, there is no point in legalising. possibly shorten the 
sentences, because i heard of some ridiculous stuff going on with that. but 
in my country anyway, they usually let you off with a warning the first

you're so hellbent on not giving up your precious weed.

And, yeah, I've met a few cool cops (thank fucking God!), but I still don't 
trust them.  That's because I don't trust the system.

I mainly pity the assholes who can't afford health care and are stuck in a 
state that doesn't support medicinal marijuana and are forced to keep 
taking drugs that do nothing but harm in you the long run. 

I just wish they would legalize marijuana everywhere, honestly...I hate 
waiting around for the damn weed man.
comments.author: SirSwagnificent

comments.text:
+SirSwagnificent Yeah, and the worst thing is they take a lot more power 
than even all the power they're given and I worry and worry that I need to 
do something, for example about my situation I mentioned, but I don't think 
there's actually anything one can do. I still feel like I need to though. 

Thanks a lot man, really appreciate it, it's great to hear. I do think that 
that's a sad thing because if the drug laws and prostitution laws were 
changed, it would change the whole society, the whole world even. Suddenly 
crimes would become things like Assault, Murder, Rape, Theft and people 
could begin to trust the system just enough to feel like they could make a 
difference.

New police officers would become good people, maybe not all of them, but 
not ALL of them would be bad or at least very ignorant and stupid people 
anymore and after that, the Police Chiefs and heads of department could 
also be good people who joined to stop murders and rapes it could change a 
lot I think. 

Also, people would stop being so paranoid and hateful of police and their 
fellow man if prostitution and drug laws were changed, right now, Millions 
of people identify with criminal culture because they feel they HAVE to 
because society has forced them into the box of being a criminal because 
they like to exercise freedom of their own self. 

Right now, police are by definition the stupidest people in society because 
all it takes is . . . actually, I was about to say all it takes is a google 
search on the effects of Weed and other drugs for it to become obvious why 
you shouldn't become a policeman, but actually it's even more simple than 
that it's simple common fucking sense and basic deductive logic that it 
could NEVER make sense to put somebody away for a victimless crime even if 
smoking weed made your head instantly explode it would make no sense. So 
it's not just being totally ignorant of all the laws they enforce, but it's 
actually even more stupid than that, they have to lack basic reasoning 
skills let alone the ability to use Google. 

Basic reasoning skills is supposed to make us human. Pigs are effectively 
sub-human. I really see them as less than actual pigs, every single one of 
them. Apart from maybe in Portugal, there could be a good policeman or two 
since at least very small amounts of possession of drugs are 
decriminalized, I don't know what the laws are for prostitution.
comments.author: AEgamesFtw

comments.text:
Fucking preach it, man.  Sorry things went down with you like the did.  
That really fucking sucks.  Yeah, it's pretty dumb that smoking a cigarette 
is perfectly A-okay, but taking bong rips on some marijuana isn't?  Of 
course, I know the history behind its illegalization.  It pretty much 
proves the hypocrisy of the police system.

I recently saw a video of this guy, who just happened to be black; and he 
was videotaping himself and his friend (also black) walking down a sidewalk 
in a residential area.  He was smoking a black and mild, and he and his 
friend were just walking.  Of course, about several yards away, three 
police officers were tailing them (hence the guy video taping all this).  
They literally stopped the two black civilians on account of "jay walking" 
across a street in a residential area about 100 yards away.  Oh, not to 
mention, the main cop (fucking oinking piece of shit pig) literally digs 
his hands into the black male's pockets, which is OBVIOUSLY not legal to 
begin with.

My point is, these fucking cops are given WAY too much fucking power.  Even 
when you try to express your rights, they have some bullshit loophole to 
overpower your claims.  Fuck America.
comments.author: SirSwagnificent

comments.text:
+SirSwagnificent They might be. On the other hand, they might just be drug 
users and instead of a drink they like to unwind with a little bit of MDMA 
or Amphetamine or some Benzos and they have a balanced and overall healthy 
and productive life. Either way, there's no justification for charging them 
and making them live a paranoid, stressful and ruined life like me for 
example who has been illegally stopped and searched and now they have info 
on me and a file saying they "stopped & searched and found" something on me 
even though I had nothing illegal on me. All this kindof police shit ruins 
my life and if drugs were legal then police might be good people instead of 
ignorant, moron thugs. For example, I'm a good person and I'd consider 
being a cop if it meant helping people and not throwing their lives away 
for smoking a herb.

The mere fact of the drug laws being in place how they are, ensures that 
all police are moronic thugs by definition because they enforce THOSE 
particular laws. It's like a filter which ensures a shitty, shitty, shitty 
police system.
comments.author: AEgamesFtw

comments.text:
+AEgamesFtw
I like how you touched up on the "criminals", or drug users and how they're 
all sent to jail.  These people are obviously addled with addictive 
problems and/or psychological problems and should be sent to clinical 
reform for mental care.  Of course, that isn't as much of a financial 
investment, as, say, the jail/prison system.  America is just full of 
fucking fail, I swear.
comments.author: SirSwagnificent

comments.text:
+Zappy Zap When a drug is legalised the use of the drug goes down as well 
as overall crime. You're brainwashed. If a drug is legal then it will be 
used on its own merits, instead of for all the wrong reasons of 
"rebellion", "glorification", "misinformation", etc. What do you mean 
something else will sell? We know what will sell, because they already sell 
anyway and prohibition does nothing to stop that. Are you trying to say 
that if Marijuana is legal, people will suddenly want to buy and consume 
more cocaine? Where is the link there that makes no sense? People buy weed 
because they want weed. They buy weed from gangs because gangs sell weed. 
If weed is legal then all of the money people spend on weed won't go to 
gangs, it's that simple. The people who want cocaine are already buying 
(impure, far more dangerous and creates money for gangs and might ruin 
their life by being caught with it) cocaine.

 Not just that, but the entire concept of putting somebody in prison for 
possessing something just because it's a bad idea to consume what they 
possess is ridiculous, unethical and barbaric. Just confiscate the item and 
destroy it if it's so bad. At most, criminal charges for PRODUCTION of 
drugs could almost make sense. If these drugs were actually bad then you 
wouldn't need prison sentences to stop people using them, that would only 
work if the prison sentences were worse than the risks of the drugs . . . 
which then begs the question WHY NOT JUST HAVE THE LESSER OF TWO EVILS.

Also, at the moment people assume that because MDMA and Pot are illegal and 
they're infinitely safer than alcohol which is legal then heroin and 
cocaine are probably not as dangerous as the Government makes out also 
which results in much more problems and deaths. 

It wouldn't bring any medical costs. If all drugs were legal people would 
probably use more better drugs and we'd have to spend less repairing livers 
of alcoholics and hearts of obese people.
comments.author: AEgamesFtw

comments.text:
A few years back cigarettes where being sold on the black market when tax 
on cigarettes went up. But this is something that you can control with 
regulation, distribution and pricing instead of criminalizing and jailing 
your way out it.
comments.author: daniel213141

comments.text:
Trust me, if pot dont sell, something else will.. and if you just keep 
legalizing drug after drug.. well then you will have a pretty dangerous 
society to live in.. not to talk about the medical costs it would bring.
comments.author: Zappy Zap

comments.text:
NOT ONLY THAT, but how many more variations of the illegal drugs will be 
created?  From Bath salts to Spice and even to Krokodil, more often than 
not, it gets worse and worse with the artificial versions.  Also, by 
maintaining these drugs illegal, we're supporting terrorism.  Good job, 
America...another reason why I hate you.
comments.author: SirSwagnificent

comments.text:
+Jiggle Squirt
Yeah, gang crime wouldn't disappear, but it would decrease significantly.
comments.author: Stephen Kelly

comments.text:
True, but it's probably not as simple as that. With the infrastructure for 
illegal trade already set up, it's not going to just disappear if their 
goods can be sold legally. There is such a thing as smuggling of legal 
goods, because by doing it illegally you bypass regulations and taxes and 
that can put you in an advantageous situation. So while it would probably 
reduce "underground" activity, it's not going to just go away. If an 
illegal worker was already set up to be making huge profits, why would he 
just drop everything to go legal and make less?
comments.author: Jiggle Squirt

comments.text:
Nobody is saying that Criminals will disappear. Prohibition is universally 
credit with making the mob as wealthy as they where and as violent. The 
repeal of prohibition eliminated the violence associated with the black 
market.
"..much weed was imported that the illegal black marked crashed!.."
Good documentary! Marijuana was being sold, but for a lot less then before. 
Same thing happened with coke years later. If it where legalized there 
would not be the violence that is associated with a black market.
comments.author: daniel213141

comments.text: +Lobos222 sounds like a BIG JOB KILLER! lol
comments.author: Mariposa Brillante

comments.text: +Lobos222 Which is why all victimless crimes should not exist
comments.author: AEgamesFtw

comments.text:
"If you legalize and regulate prostitution as well, mafia will be out of 
jobs."

If that was the case. The cartels would have gone down the drain in the 80s.
Watch the documentary Cocaine Cowboys. So much weed was imported that the 
illegal black marked crashed!

Criminals just shifted over to other drugs!
comments.author: Lobos222

comments.text: S
comments.author: Shaun Lake

comments.text: +Gary Cartman Legalize victimless crimes, yes.
comments.author: AEgamesFtw

 Talk about miss information. Sounds like a fox statement to me﻿

on your nightstand in a safe or holstered on your body.

Spiking isn't an issue? Lol ok. I clearly posted that contamination was

comments.text:
+Alexander Demkin Well,, MJ has been grown "illegally" for decades and

MJ is about $100-$150 oz in Calif since 2010. Most people would rather

top_comment.author: raidpirate52

comments.text:
+raidpirate15 Lol fuck no I own guns myself. I don't support bans on 
firearms, drugs, abortions, free speech, homosexuality, large sodas or any 
other shit that the mainstream media or the political establishment might 
want to outlaw. Suprising as this may be, not everyone fits neatly into one 
side or the other of the mainstream political dichotomy that we have here 
in the US. Some people, like myself, like to do their own research and make 
their own decisions. In fact, I highly reccomend it.
comments.author: Bleach Drinker

comments.text:
Ricky Williams was a dumb ass, something was going to "ruin" his life, just 
happened to be weed.
comments.author: David Hanson

comments.text:
+raidpirate15
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Straw_man
comments.author: nightwolfsden

comments.text:
That's kinda what I was getting at.  Its hard to say there are lots of very 
successful people who indulge in whatever illegal thing they are in to 
because its not the drug that ruins them its the PR game that does it.  
There are very few highly successful people who are open about drug use for 
that reason.  As such you hear a lot of stories about the people that fuck 
up but you never hear a lot about Judges, Politicians, or other public 
personalities because they have a handle on it.  Its likely that some very 
influential people smoke pot, and its not an issue because they do their 
job, pay their taxes, go home home and crank up a Marley. The drug isn't 
the problem, the perception of it is.
comments.author: nightwolfsden

comments.text:
+normtheclone Oh but I'm sure you want guns banned and murderers to go 
free.
comments.author: raidpirate52

comments.text:
I don't really think pot ruins lives. At least not a significant number 
compared to many more mundane things in this world. Even if it does, its 
still un-American and anti-freedom to ban marijuana. Sugars and fried foods 
ruin more lives than weed, but should they be banned? Probably not, unless 
we want to live in a country like Hitler's Germany or Stalin's Russia.
comments.author: Bleach Drinker

comments.text: The silly law ruined him, not pot.
comments.author: nightwolfsden
